title: 3 Easy Ways to Exclude Certain Words from Google Search

steps.title: Use - to remove a specific word from the search results.
steps.content: Use - to remove a specific word from the search results. When there's a minus sign followed by a word, Google Search knows to ignore any results containing that word. [1] X Research source For example, if you want to search for "best laptops" and exclude certain models, input the following search: best laptops -HP If you want to include more than one exclusion, add another minus sign with the word or phrase. Be sure to include a space between each. This will look like: best laptops -HP -Chromebook

steps.title: Use -" " to exclude results with a specific phrase or term.
steps.content: Use -" " to exclude results with a specific phrase or term. In normal Google searches , putting a phrase in quotations is a neat search trick to find results containing specific words. By adding a minus sign, Google will exclude those specific words. For example, if you want to search for "best laptops" and want to exclude the term "budget laptops", input the following search: best laptops -"budget laptops"

steps.title: Use site:
steps.content: Use site: to exclude results from specific websites. The "site:" tag allows you to ignore any searches from a website. This can be helpful if you want to find less popular results when searching the internet . For example, if you want to search for "best laptops" and want to exclude the Amazon website, input the following search: best laptops -site:amazon.com You can also use Google to search within specific websites by removing the minus sign.

steps.title: Use the Advanced Search form
steps.content: Use the Advanced Search form . Many Google users report that the using the minus/hyphen symbol to exclude words and phrases doesn't work as reliably as it used to. If you're unable to exclude certain words from your search, go to https://www.google.com/advanced_search . Here, you can enter your search terms, and enter your exclusion(s) into the "none of these words" field for better results.

steps.title: Try excluding additional words.
steps.content: Try excluding additional words. If you're trying to exclude a word that's in most or all of the results, Google may ignore the modifier. Google also may show you results containing a variation of the excluded word, such as misspellings or pluralizations. You can i improve your results by excluding even more words or concepts, and adding more keywords to your query. For example, if you're searching for the emotion "euphoria" but don't want to see results about the TV show Euphoria , you'll still see results about the show using euphoria -tv . In this case, a search like euphoria emotion -tv or euphoria -tv -series would yield better results.

steps.title: Make sure you're not searching the Shopping page.
steps.content: Make sure you're not searching the Shopping page. The - modifier doesn't work on the Google Shopping page. As of now, there's no way to exclude specific words and phrases when searching Google's Shopping tab.
